item.title: Push Notifications in Python
item.description:
Description

Tim Penhey https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/133/ An in-depth exploration of implementing push notifications to mobile devices using a python stack.
item.dc:creator: Tim Penhey

item.title: A path to multi(arbitrary)-precision, distributed scientific computation with Python3.
item.description:
Description

Boris Daszuta https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/138/ On occasion scientific computations at double(quadruple) precision are simply not sufficient. In lieu of the usual NumPy and SciPy one can instead make use of mpmath or SymPy. For a 'large-scale' calculation one must appeal to parallelism and indeed distributed resources (eg. Dask-distributed). We describe a package that provides for library delegation based on calculation requirements at runtime.
item.dc:creator: Boris Daszuta

item.title: Auckland Transport APIs
item.description:
Description

Tomislav Skunca https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/112/ Presenting currently available transport-related APIs in Auckland. What is currently available, limitations, opportunities and future plans.
item.dc:creator: Tomislav Skunca

item.title: await kittens()
item.description:
Description

Lee Symes https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/128/ This talk will work through getting pictures(of kittens and other cute things) off Flickr using asyncio in Python 3.5. Showing how to build up from synchronous code to asynchronous code and how to make use of Python 3.5's new language features like async for and async with.
item.dc:creator: Lee Symes

item.title: Bluetooth Low Energy
item.description:
Description

Jeremy Stott https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/139/ How does your smart watch work for tens of hours before needing to be charged? Let's check out Bluetooth Low Energy, and how to use Python to maximise fun.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Stott

item.title: Brainstorm your own Artificial Neural Network in Python
item.description:
Description

Holger Spill https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/119/ Have you ever wanted to teach your computer how to recognise handwritten digits? The difficulty of visual pattern recognition becomes apparent when writing a computer program to recognize shapes. What seems easy when we do it ourselves quickly becomes complex when done programmatically. This talk will explore some of the concepts of Neural Networks with Brainstorm ‚Äì an open-source Python library.
item.dc:creator: Holger Spill

item.title: Deciding between continuity and change in your Open Source communtiy
item.description:
Description

Christopher Neugebauer https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/131/ When you‚Äôre a community of volunteers, it can be difficult to justify a change from outdated software to something newer. In this talk, we‚Äôll cover how to make that decision: how to identify and engage with stakeholders within a community; the value of prototypes in maintaining interest; and what a cost-benefit analysis might look like when your currencies are human joy, and burnout prevention.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Neugebauer

item.title: Digital image processing - From atom to pixel and back
item.description:
Description

Alex Dong https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/125/ (Start cut of talk is correct; speaker wasn't introduced. Speaker requested all lights off for talk).

This talk gives a brief tour to the complex technical process that happens between we take a photo with our camera and the photo gets printed onto a piece of paper. Be prepared for a fun, wild and intense session!
item.dc:creator: Alex Dong

item.title: Ethics in the early days: politics and the computing profession
item.description:
Description

Janet Toland https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/150/ This presentation will consider how early computer professionals viewed their social responsibilities to the wider world, and how their decisions have influenced todays profession.
item.dc:creator: Janet Toland

item.title: Golang for Python Devs
item.description:
Description

Dana Garifullina https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/123/ Python is a popular language and we all know why, however it‚Äôs hard to ignore the hype around new programming languages like Scala, Rust and Go. Billed as competition to Python, Go was the most intriguing one for me. In this talk I share experiences, compare two languages and answer the questions: why try Go? How easy or frustrating is it? And will you end up preferring it over Python?
item.dc:creator: Dana Garifullina

item.title: Graphing when your Facebook friends are awake
item.description:
Description

Alexander Hogue https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/115/ Look I‚Äôm not really sure why but I think I made a thing that makes graphs of when people are online on Facebook. It sounds kinda creepy and uh it is. We'll talk about the struggle of finding a good graphing library, so come along and roleplay as the NSA. Àô‚ÄÜÕú üÀô
item.dc:creator: Alexander Hogue

item.title: Hear no evil, see no evil, patch no evil: Or, how to monkey-patch safely.
item.description:
Description

Graham Dumpleton https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/155/ Monkey patching has come to have a reputation of being somewhat evil. In this talk you will learn what monkey patching is all about and whether its reputation as being evil is truly justified.
item.dc:creator: Graham Dumpleton

item.title: Leveraging Python to Automate GIS Processes and Provide Extended Analytical Capabilities
item.description:
Description

Hamish Kingsbury, Neal Johnston https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/117/ Geographical Information Systems (GIS) is a developing spatial technology that uses the Python programming language. Using commercial and open source libraries, GIS analysis and development can be automated and extended beyond the regular capabilities of desktop software. This can include spatial analysis, data mining and automatic map generation.
item.dc:creator: Hamish Kingsbury

item.title: Lightning Talks Friday
item.dc:creator: Various speakers

item.title: Lightning Talks Saturday
item.dc:creator: Various speakers

item.title: Making randomly generated guitar effect patches that don't sound terrible
item.description:
Description

Steve Baker https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/140/ Modern guitar effects processors are available which have flexible and complex signal processing pipelines and can be controlled remotely via MIDI. I attempt to use python to create good and interesting sounds by randomly generating effects patches.
item.dc:creator: Steve Baker

item.title: Making sense of setup.py
item.description:
Description

Tim McNamara https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/122/ This talk will guide you through the process of wrapping your scraps and scripts into dapper Python packages. Now when you want to re-use some of the code that you've written before, you'll be able to without resorting to an ugly kludge. No more copy & paste, no path hacks - just beautiful, easy to install code.
item.dc:creator: Tim McNamara

item.title: Making the web go fast with jelly snakes and raspberry twizzlers
item.description:
Description

Jack Skinner https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/114/ In this fun & playful session I‚Äôll take you on a journey from HTTP/1.1 to HTTP/2 enjoying the sights & delights of its new features along the way. With features like multiplexing, yesterdays best practices are now tomorrow‚Äôs anti-patterns - so what does this mean your app or API? HTTP/2 is changing the game for performance & it‚Äôs all explained of course, using jelly snakes & raspberry twizzlers.
item.dc:creator: Jack Skinner

item.title: Middle-Out Python Development
item.description:
Description

Ben Shaw https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/116/ Too often when developing Python web apps we first choose a framework and database, then code to their rules and restrictions. It's only later that we start thinking about our application's business logic. If we reverse the order and work on our logic first it can make code easier to test, and let us make more informed decisions of what frameworks and data-stores best suit our project.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shaw

item.title: More testing with fewer tests
item.description:
Description

Clinton Roy https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/113/ We all wish we were were testing more, but tests are ugly, a pain to write and are brittle. Property based testing helps to solve all of these problems. Now, with Hypothesis, Python has an outstanding toolkit to write property based tests.
item.dc:creator: Clinton Roy

item.title: Practical Python Async for Dummies
item.description:
Description

Grant Paton-Simpson https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/121/ What's the point of faster computers if our code spends most of its time waiting for slower processes to complete. Shouldn't we be using asynchronous code to make lots of things happen simultaneously? Probably, but isn't that really tricky to do? The goal of this talk is to work through some very simple snippets of Python code that make common tasks much, much faster with minimal fuss.
item.dc:creator: Grant Paton-Simpson

item.title: Preventing Cat-astrophes with GNU MediaGoblin
item.description:
Description

Ben Sturmfels https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/124/ What would happen to all the cat videos if YouTube were to disappear? It would be a cat-atstrophe! GNU MediaGoblin is Python-based media publishing system for artists ‚Äî an alternative to centralised, censored and surveilled systems like Flickr, YouTube and SoundCloud. MediaGoblin gives people privacy, choice and control of their own media, something we need now more than ever.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sturmfels

item.title: PygData : Python in BigData
item.description:
Description

Krupesh Desai https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/145/ A Concise overview of the term "Big Data" with simple examples followed by highlighting areas where Python is widely used in big data solutions.
item.dc:creator: Krupesh Desai

item.title: Rust for Pythonistas
item.description:
Description

Robert Collins https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/136/ Rust is a new systems programming language iniated and sponsored by Mozilla thats making some waves - its the core for servo, Firefox's new parallel render engine, amongst other things. Find out how it is relevant to Pythonistas even in these modern mypy days, as well as interop between Rust and Python, and differences in programming style.
item.dc:creator: Robert Collins

item.title: Scientific Hooliganism - what we can learn from the first hack in history
item.description:
Description

Lilly Ryan https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/135/ In 1903, Guglielmo Marconi prepared to unveil his world-first, long-distance wireless communication technology to the Royal Institution in London. He was looking forward to roaring success - but he didn't count upon falling victim to the first hack in history. Over a century later, the tech industry is still repeating Marconi's mistakes. What can the FOSS and infosec communities learn from 1903?
item.dc:creator: Lilly Ryan

item.title: Some 10,000ft views of DNA Sequence Data using Python and R
item.description:
Description

Alan McCulloch https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/132/ To observe interesting structure in data we often need to throw away quite alot of information ! This talk is centered around a small python library I have developed, and some applications that use it to help find structure in large DNA datasets, mainly as part of quality control strategies used in a sequencing lab.
item.dc:creator: Alan McCulloch

item.title: SSL all the things
item.description:
Description

Markus Holtermann https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/134/ Over the last few years SSL/TLS encryption of websites has risen tremendously. The Let‚Äôs Encrypt organization makes that pretty easy. And you can use it, too. For free! In this talk I'll show how to integrate SSL/TLS and point out some common pitfalls.
item.dc:creator: Markus Holtermann

item.title: Tai Chi Principles for Mindful Programmers
item.description:
Description

Barry Warsaw https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/141/ I've been playing music all my life, programming for almost 40 years, using Python for more than 20, and studying tai chi for nearly 15. These life-long pursuits continue to reveal their truths as fun and interesting vocations and avocations. My study of tai chi has had particularly profound consequences and in this talk I'll explore some of its applications to the world of programming.
item.dc:creator: Barry Warsaw

item.title: The dangerous, exquisite art of safely handing user-uploaded files
item.description:
Description

Tom Eastman https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/110/ "Come On, What Harm Can a User Profile photo Do?". The most dangerous thing you can do with your web application is allow people to upload files to it, not even the best web frameworks can fully protect you from the range of damage that can be done. I'll show you every scary thing I know about that can be done with a file upload, and how to protect yourself from -- hopefully -- most of them.
item.dc:creator: Tom Eastman

item.title: The Power ‚ö°Ô∏è and Responsibility üòì of Unicode Adoption ‚ú®
item.description:
Description

Katie McLaughlin https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/107/ Unicode is the way of the future, with thousands of hours being spent to incorporate it into legacy systems. But what about Emoji adoption? From the technical to the social aspects, this talk will cover why the extended character set provided by the Unicode standard needs to be treated with responsibility by users and platforms alike.
item.dc:creator: Katie McLaughlin

item.title: Universal Second Factor authentication, or why 2FA today is wubalubadubdub?
item.description:
Description

Yuriy Ackermann https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/111/ Today main 2FA solutions are OTP(TOTP, HOTP), RSA keys and SMS. All these solutions lack UX, security and privacy, easy to phish, and mostly not standardized. In this talk we will introduce FIDO U2F protocol, talk about its key strength, overview the protocol, review current protocol support, and for desert do some demos.
item.dc:creator: Yuriy Ackermann

item.title: Use Workflow-as-a-Service without writing python code
item.description:
Description

Lingxian Kong https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/120/ Things will be in a mess if you want to implement a program that have a lot of tasks running in any language, including Python. Most of complicated processes consist of lots of steps, which should be executed in particular sequence. Mistral(implemented in Python) can automate such orchestration of steps and provide many other features, leave things to Mistral without writing your own Python code.
item.dc:creator: Lingxian Kong

item.title: Warpdrive, making Python web application deployment magically easy.
item.description:
Description

Graham Dumpleton https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/108/ Deploying Python web applications is too hard. You either have to understand some arcane configuration syntax, or have to dig through an encyclopaedic volume of options. It shouldn't have to be this hard. In this talk you will see how 'warpdrive', with the right sort of magic, can make Python web application deployment easy.
item.dc:creator: Graham Dumpleton

item.title: What's holding you back from connecting with others?
item.description:
Description

Lucy Bain https://kiwi.pycon.org/schedule/presentation/142/ We interact with people every day, let's do it a bit better! First I'll cover a bit about improving how you connect with people day to day. Then we'll move into participating in your communities and how to make it a better experience. Finally, I'll discuss some ways to organise events that work for you, so you get the most out of the experience.
item.dc:creator: Lucy Bain
